Fig. 1 Illustration of 12 TM-TCNQ candidates. Bluer and redder colours labelled correspond to higher activities for the ORR and the OER. The colours of transition metals (TM), nitrogen (N), carbon (C), hydrogen atoms (H) are in magenta, blue, gray and white respectively. TM-TCNQs with crosses are ruled out because they do not meet the stability criteria. Fig. 2 Scaling relations between the adsorption free energies of adsorbates on TM-TCNQ monolayers. Black: *O vs. *OH; red: *OOH vs. *OH. The dashed horizontal line shows the O2 initial state at 4.92 eV. Fig. 3 Four-electron-transfer ORR pathway through the intermediates OOH*, O* and OH*, and contour map of the ORR limiting overpotential (η) as a function of Gibbs free energies of O*-OH* and OH*. Oxygen (O) atoms are coloured in red. Fig. 4 Gibbs free energy landscape of Fe-TCNQ for the ORR at different electrode potentials in an acidic medium. Fig. 5 Four-electron-transfer OER pathway through the intermediates OH*, O* and OOH*, and contour map of the OER limiting overpotential (η) as a function of Gibbs free energies of O*-OH* and OH*. Fig. 6 Limiting overpotentials of TM-TCNQ (TM = Mn, Fe, Co) towards the ORR and the OER by coordinating Cl, CO, NO, CN as axial the ligands as well as the ligand free monolayers for comparison, respectively. 2D transition metal–TCNQ sheets as bifunctional single-atom catalysts for oxygen reduction and evolution reaction (ORR/OER) Qingming Deng a b Jiong Zhao c Tiantian Wu b Guibin Chen a Heine Anton Hansen b ⁎ Tejs Vegge b ⁎ a Physics Department and Jiangsu Key Laboratory for Chemistry of Low-Dimensional Materials, Huaiyin Normal University, Huaian 223300, China Physics Department and Jiangsu Key Laboratory for Chemistry of Low-Dimensional Materials Huaiyin Normal University Huaian 223300 China b Department of Energy Conversion and Storage, Technical University of Denmark, Fysikvej, 2800 Kgs. Graphical abstract Functionalized Fe-TCNQ monolayers serve as high-performance bifunctional ORR/OER catalysts. The identification of catalytically active and stable bifunctional electrocatalysts for the oxygen reduction and evolution reaction (ORR/OER) would revolutionize rechargeable metal-air batteries and regenerative fuel cell technologies. In this study, we use density functional theory (DFT) calculations to systemically investigate 2D transition metal based tetracyanoquinodimethane (TM–TCNQ, TM = Cr-Cu, Ru-Ag, Pt, Ir) monolayers with single TM atoms catalysts (SACs) distributed periodically with high density. We calculate a lower limiting overpotential of ηlim = 0.33 V for Fe-TCNQ yielding a higher expected activity than that of Pt metal (0.48 V) for the ORR under acidic conditions. The catalytic performance of Fe-TCNQ for OER is, however, surpassed by Ni-TCNQs (ηlim = 0.46 V), which is identified as the highest among the candidates. By applying grafting axial ligands and external strain, the adsorption strength of reaction intermediates on TM reactive sites can be further optimized and enhances the activities of Mn-, Fe- and Ni-TCNQs for the ORR or the OER. Here, Fe-TCNQ-Cl (ηlim = 0.27/0.55 V), followed by Fe-TCNQ-CO (ηlim = 0.67/0.43 V), are predicted as novel, high-performance bifunctional ORR/OER catalysts with comparable limiting overpotentials to those of the best commercially used electrocatalysts, Pt (ORR: ηlim = 0.48 V) and RuO2 (OER: ηlim = 0.42 V). In addition, the recently synthesized Fe-TCNQ possess excellent conductivity with fast electron transfer during the catalytic reactions. These results show 2D TM-TCNQ monolayers are durable, low-cost, and efficient catalysts for the ORR and the OER in metal-air batteries and fuel cells. Keywords Computational screening Oxygen reduction reaction Oxygen evolution reaction Bifunctional ORR/OER catalyst Density functional theory 1 Introduction The rising energy demand and depletion of fossil fuels have led to increasing interest in alternative energy sources. Additionally, fossil fuels are not renewable and generate deleterious combustion products such as CO, CO2, NO, SO2, and even hazards of heavy metal contamination posing serious challenges to human health, and environmental protection [1]. Sustainable power generation technologies are regarded as a promising solution, and a good example of such technologies is the proton exchange membrane (PEM) fuel cell [2,3], where hydrogen is oxidized at the anode producing protons which are transported through the membrane to the cathode where the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) takes place during the production of water. However, slow oxygen kinetics on the cathode and the use of precious metal based electrocatalysts, such as platinum (Pt), hinder widespread commercialization [4]. Likewise, the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) in water splitting electrocatalysts also requires noble metals namely ruthenium or iridium-based catalysts [5–7]. Thus, scientists are continuously seeking new families of low-cost electrocatalysts whose catalytic performances are comparable or even higher than those of noble metal based materials [8]. Moreover, finding bifunctional ORR and OER electrocatalyst is a key step in rechargeable metal-air batteries and regenerative fuel cell technologies [9]. Any technical breakthrough would therefore be greatly beneficial for easing the contradiction between supply and demand of energy and solving the environmental problems with burning fossil fuels. Metal-free electrodes have recently attracted attention as alternatives to rare metal containing catalysts that can be used to catalyse the ORR or OER effectively [10]. For instance, vertical aligned nitrogen-doped carbon nanotube (VA-NCNT) arrays can catalyse a 4e− ORR process with a 3-times higher electrocatalytic activity and better long-term operational stability than that of widely used platinum/C electrodes [11]. Another way to reduce the usage of precious metals is mixing or alloying with cheaper metals, as the adsorption of reaction intermediates can be tuned to enhance the ORR or OER activity. The third approach involves the replacement of noble metals with much cheaper 3d transition-metal catalysts supported on one- or two-dimensional materials. Typical examples are the transition metal-N4 macrocycles (TM-N4), e.g. phthalocyanine (TM-Pc) [12–17], TM-porphyrin-like complexes (TM-PP) [18–20] and TM coordinate hexaaminobenzene-base polymer (TM-HAP) [21,22], whose catalytic performances have been extensively studied both experimentally and theoretically. One big advantage of two dimensional single-atom catalysts (SACs) is that the various kinds of single metal atom sites are ordered and strongly anchored into the pores offering great potential for achieving high-activity catalysts with maximal usage of the transition metals [23,24]. Besides, most of such two-dimensional metal-organic frameworks are metallic allowing fast electron transport, which is particularly important for high activity electrocatalysts. Analogous to the TM-N4 complexes discussed above, a series of two-dimensional transition metal–tetracyanoquinodimethane (TM–TCNQ, TM = Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Zn, Ag) monolayers have been synthesized with unique electronic, magnetic, and photoactive properties [25–32]. Especially, embedded TM atoms are distributed periodically with high density (ca. 2.4 × 1023/g), which makes TM–TCNQ monolayers promising single-atom-catalysts [33]. Wang et al. predicted Fe-TCNQ can serve as an efficient electrocatalyst for the ORR in acidic and alkaline conditions by DFT [34]. The activity range of the TM-TCNQs remains, however, largely unexplored, and their capacity as bifunctional ORR/OER electrocatalyst is still unknown. Inspired by the realized structures and the present simulations, we therefore systematically investigate twelve TM-TCNQs’ stabilities, structures, and catalytic behaviors for the ORR and the OER by using first-principle calculations (TM = Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Ru, Rh, Ir, Pt, Pd, Ag). Our calculations reveal that Fe-TCNQ possesses the lowest thermodynamic limiting overpotential (ηlim = 0.33 V) via a four-electron reduction resulting in a higher expected activity per site than that of Pt metal (η = 0.48 V) for the ORR [20,35,36]. The catalytic performance of Ni-TCNQ sheet for the OER is identified as the highest among 12 candidates. Grafting axial ligands and applying external strain can further enhance the activities, especially towards the OER, attributed to optimized adsorption energies and violation of the scaling relations among the OER intermediates. Most importantly, Fe-TCNQ monolayers with ligands of Cl and CO are predicted as bifunctional ORR/OER catalysts whose calculated limiting overpotentials are comparable or even lower than the two best electrocatalysts Pt [20,35,36] and RuO2 [37]. 2 Computational methods All calculations in this study are carried out using spin-polarized density function theory (DFT) calculations as implemented in the Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP) [7,22] to explore the activities for the ORR and the OER on TM-TCNQ monolayers. The exchange-correlation interactions are approximated by the RPBE functional [38] within the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) [39], which provides better chemisorption energies than PBE. The kinetic energy cutoff of the plane-wave basis set is 500 eV, and dipole corrections are applied in the direction perpendicular to the TM-TCNQ plane. The thickness of the vacuum layer between TM-TCNQ planes is set to be more than 20 Å, which is sufficiently large to avoid interlayer interactions. The electronic SCF tolerance is set to 10−5 eV. Fully relaxed geometries and lattice constant are obtained by optimizing all atomic positions until the Hellmann–Feynman forces are below 0.02 eV/Å. The k-point sampling is 4 × 4 × 1 in the first Brillouin zone for structural optimizations, while a 8 × 8 × 1 sampling is used for the density of states (DOS) calculations. Solvation of intermediates on the active site is considered through implicit solvation with a dielectric constant of 78.4 for water [40], The solvation model has been shown to be important for the description of trends in ORR/OER SACs [41,42]. VASP input files are prepared by the atomistic simulation environment (ASE) [43]. The structures of transition states (TS) are identified by the climbing image nudged elastic band method (CI-NEB) [44]. At least eight intermediate images are constructed along the reaction pathway between the initial state (IS) and the final state (FS) with a spring force of 5.0 eV/Å. The minimum energy path is optimized with the fast inertial relaxation engine (FIRE) [45] until the maximum force on the band is below 0.05 eV/Å. The DFT formation energies of OOH*, O*, and OH* are calculated with reference to H2O(g) and H2(g) according to the following Eqs. (1)–(3): (1) Δ E ads OOH ∗ = E TCNQ - OOH - E TCNQ - 2 E H 2 O - 3 / 2 E H 2 (2) Δ E ads O ∗ = E TCNQ - O - E TCNQ - E H 2 O - E H 2 (3) Δ E ads O H ∗ = E TCNQ - OH - E TCNQ - E H 2 O - 1 / 2 E H 2 where E TCNQ-OOH, E TCNQ-O, E TCNQ-O are the energies with adsorbates binding to the transition metal of TCNQ complexes, E H2O and E H2 are the total energy of single isolated H2O and H2 molecule, respectively. The computational hydrogen electrode (CHE) model [35] is applied to evaluate the change in Gibbs free energy of adsorbates under acid conditions by Eq. (4). (4) Δ G = Δ E ads + Δ E ZPE + T Δ S + Δ G U where E ads is calculated from Eqs. (1) to (3). ΔEZPE and TΔS are the zero point energy change and entropy change upon adsorption, respectively. Here, ΔEZPE  + TΔS is approximated to be 0.4, 0.05 and 0.35 eV for OOH, O, and OH adsorbates, respectively [35,46,47]. ΔG U = −neU, where n is the number of electrons transferred and U is the electrode potential versus the reversible hydrogen electrode [19]. 3 Results and discussion Irreversible detachment of the central transition metal atom from the catalyst significantly limits catalyst durability. To elucidate the stabilities of TM-TCNQ monolayers, we firstly examine the energetic difference (E diff) between the embedding energy of the metals (E emb) and the cohesive energy (E c) of the bulk metal according to the equation: (5) E diff = E emb - E c = E TM - TCNQ - E TCNQ - E M - E bulk - N E M / N where E TM-TCNQ, E TCNQ, E bulk, E M are total energies of the TM-TCNQ system, the metal-free TCNQ, the bulk metal unit cell containing N metal atoms and the isolated single metal in the same slab, respectively. Negative values of E diff, here in the range from −0.81 to −2.89 eV (Table S1), indicate the metal atoms prefer to be embedded into the TCNQ rather than forming bulk metal or clusters likely because of the very strong coordination bonds formed as nitrogen atoms donate 2p electron pairs to the vacant d orbitals of metal. Thus, Cr and Mn-TCNQ are expected to have the largest E diff due to the relative high fraction of vacant d orbitals. Secondly, the removal energy (E re ) is calculated to evaluate the feasibility of metal substitution by hydrogenation of TCNQ in solution by the following equation: (6) E re = E TM - TCNQ + E H 2 - E H 2 - TCNQ - E bulk / N where E TM-TCNQ, E H2-TCNQ, E bulk are total energies of the TM-TCNQ system, hydrogenated TCNQ and the basic unit cell containing N metal atoms, respectively. E H2 is the standard free energy of H2 molecules. Negative values of Ere for Cr-, Mn-, Fe-TCNQs (−1.22 to −0.11 eV) reveal that these metal atoms can coordinate relative strongly with four nitrogen atoms in a square pyramidal configuration rather than being substituted by H2 (or protons and electrons) in Table S1. However, the central metal atoms are easily substituted by protons in Ru-, Pd-, Ag-, and Pt-TCNQs because of the larger positive values of E re (>0.45 eV). Hydrogen substitution on the central metal atom in Co-, Rh-, Cu-, Ni- and Ir-TCNQs is moderate with small removal energies from 0.06 to 0.33 eV. Thirdly, in acidic electrochemical electrolyte transition metals might oxidize and the most stable form of the transition metal can be a cation rather than the bulk metal. To access the stability in acid of these corroding transition metals, we also calculate the acidic stability as (7) E acid = E diff + n e ( U - U 0 ) for the corroding elements. Here n is the number of electrons transferred in the oxidation, e is the elementary charge, U is the catalyst potential, and U0 is the experimental reversible potential for the metal redox reaction [18]. We assume a catalyst working potential of 0.75 V. Because Pd, Ag, Pt and Ir have standard reversible potentials for oxidation above 0.75 V, we consider these elements to be not corroding at 0.75 V and set E acid = E diff for these. We see (in Table S1, Supporting Information) that early 3d transition metals in TM-TCNQ are thermodynamically unstable at a representable operating potential of 0.75 V vs RHE, and that Fe and Co are less unstable than Cr and Mn. In brief, by applying three descriptors to evaluate the stability of the TM-TCNQ monolayers, the stability of these candidates towards metal atoms clustering follow the trend Cr > Mn > Fe > Co > Rh > Cu > Ni > Ir for TCNQ monolayers in aqueous solution. At oxidizing operating potentials, the trend is largely reversed Ir > Rh > Cu > Co > Fe > Ni > Mn > Cr. While, the unlisted candidates should be ruled out due to not satisfying the stability criterion. The optimized structure of Fe-TCNQ is shown in Fig. 1 , as an example. The TM-TCNQs have rectangular unit cells with lattice constants listed in Table S1. Similar to graphene and boron nitride sheets, the structures of all the candidates are all perfect 2D atomic sheets without buckling. The bond length between Fe and the nearest neighboring N atom is 1.853 Å which is 5% shorter than the value of 1.946 Å in FePc. Except for Cu, Pd, and Ag, the TM-N bond lengths of TCNQ are all shorter than the TM-Pc bond length as shown in Table S1. Bader charge analysis suggests each highly electronegative nitrogen atom carries −1.24 |e|, and the neighbouring Fe and C atoms carry 1.19 |e| and 0.77 |e| positive charge, indicating that the bonding between N and Fe/C is largely covalent. In most cases, the spin and oxidation states of TM-TCNQ complexes listed in Table S1 are quite similar to other metal-N4 coordination materials, such as TM-Pc [17], TM-N4-gra [46], TM-CAP [21]. Interestingly, Ni in the TCNQ monolayer as a “high-spin” complex carries 1.14 μB magnetic moment leading to a + 2 oxidation state, whereas Ni-CAP is nonmagnetic (based on a previous study[21] and our calculations). Thus, small differences in atomic geometries of TM-N4 moieties can have quite different electronic structure leading to great influence on adsorbates’ binding energies and therefore their catalytic performances for the ORR and the OER. As proposed by Nørskov et al. [35], the activity of the ORR and the OER is mainly governed by the adsorption energy of key reaction intermediates, because the kinetics of proton coupled electron transfer to the reaction intermediates is fast even at room temperature. According to the Sabatier principle, if intermediates interact too strongly with the TM-TCNQ monolayer, the active sites of the catalyst are poisoned; whereas, if the interactions are too weak, it is difficult to activate reactants or intermediates and launch the catalytic process. Therefore, identifying promising materials with “just right” adsorption energies of the reaction intermediates is a challenge. Via the four-electron reaction pathway, the overall formation energy toward the ORR is 4.92 eV, so the ideal adsorption free energies of OOH*, O* and OH* are 3.69, 2.46, and 1.23 eV with consecutive intermediates differing by 1.23 eV. In Table S2, the adsorption free energies of 12 candidates are reported. The trend in intermediate binding strength is Cr > Ru > Mn > Fe > Co > Ni > Ir > Rh > Cu > Pd > Pt > Ag. It is well known the adsorption energies correlate strongly with d-band centres [38,48]. Deep/negative d-band centers correspond to low reactivities of the transition metal when only a small proportion of d orbitals lie above the Fermi level. From Fig. S1 and Table S2, we can see that the trend in d-band centers follows the trend in adsorption energies with the increase of the atomic number of the TM atoms. Thus, the performance of the ORR and the OER can be well described by the trend in d-band centres, which may guide better design of electrocatalysts. Besides, the electronic local density of states (LDOS) projected on the TM and the total density of states (DOS) reveal the TM-TCNQs are all found to be metallic at the applied level of theory (GGA-DFT), except Pt-TCNQ whose band gap reaches 0.71 eV. Metallic conductivity guarantees fast electron transfer during the electrochemical reactions, a feature consistent with TM-CAPs [21]. First, we consider a dissociative mechanism where chemisorbed O2 dissociates into two O atoms on the catalyst surface. From the structures of TM-TCNQs, because the central metal atom is isolated and embedded into the plane of the TM-TCNQ, we expect the catalyst is unable to provide enough reactive sites to accommodate two O atoms and the barrier should be quite high. A previous study [34] found that O2 dissociation is difficult, as it has a large barrier of over 2 eV on Fe-TCNQ. Because stronger binding of adsorbates usually corresponds to a lower barrier of O2 dissociation [49], we only need to consider O2 dissociation on Cr- and Mn-TCNQs in the present study. With high activation energies of 1.14 eV and 1.34 eV for O2 dissociation calculated by CI-NEB method, the dissociative mechanism is unlikely to occur, and we turn our attention to the associative mechanism in the following. 3.1 The oxygen reduction reaction and oxygen evolution reaction catalyzed by TM-TCNQ We investigate the 4-electron ORR in acidic solution via the following pathway: (9) * + O2(g) + H+ + e− → OOH* (10) OOH* + H+ + e− → O* + H2O (11) O* + H+ + e− → OH* (12) OH* + H+ + e− → * + H2O where * denotes an active site on the catalyst. According to Eqs. (9)–(12), the reaction Gibbs free energy can be written as (13) ΔG 1 = ΔG ads(OOH*) − 4.92 eV (14) ΔG 2 = ΔG ads(O*) − ΔG ads(OOH*) (15) ΔG 3 = ΔG ads(OH*) − ΔG ads(O*) (16) ΔG 4 = −ΔG ads(OH*) Fig. 2 shows the scaling relations of ΔG(OH*) vs ΔG(O*) and ΔG(OH*) vs ΔG(OOH*). They can be expressed as a function of ΔG(OH*) by (17) ΔG(O*) = 1.82ΔG(OH*) + 0.31 eV (18) ΔG(OOH*) = 0.83ΔG(OH*) + 3.19 eV Strong linear relationships of Eqs. (17) and (18) with high coefficients of determination (R2 = 0.90, 0.98) and very small root mean square error (0.09 eV, 0.005 eV) can be found for OH* vs O*, and OH* vs OOH*, respectively. The slope of 0.83 and a constant separation of 3.19 eV of OH* vs OOH* have been attributed to the similar bond order of M-OH and M-OOH bonds, and is consistent with those of metal and metal oxide surfaces [36,37]. ΔG ads is calculated from Eqs. (1)–(4). The Gibbs free energy of O2 (4.92 eV) is taken from the experimental value of the reaction 2H2O → O2 + 2H2. The first step in the ORR pathway is O2 being hydrogenated to OOH* through coupled proton electron transfer. Then OOH* is attacked by an additional proton-electron pair to form atomic oxygen and a water molecule. O* is then further hydrogenated to OH*, before the second H2O formed. We neglect the small barriers of proton coupled electron transfer [50] in this work, in which case the reaction kinetics is only determined by the reaction free energy of each step. The activity of an ORR catalyst can be evaluated by the thermodynamic limiting potential (Ulim) and limiting overpotential (ηlim). Based on the computational hydrogen electrode (CHE) model [35], the limiting potential (Ulim) can be calculated from Eq. (19) by determining the greatest free energy increase of all reaction steps. (19) U lim = - max Δ G 1 , Δ G 2 , Δ G 3 , Δ G 4 / e The limiting overpotential is calculated as the absolute deviation between the calculated limiting potential and the 4e− ORR equilibrium potential from Eq. (20). (20) η lim = 1.23 - U lim = 1.23 + max Δ G 1 , Δ G 2 , Δ G 3 , Δ G 4 / e Lower ηlim represents a better ORR performance. The reaction step with the greatest increase in free energy determines Ulim and ηlim, and we refer in the following to this step as the limiting step. The limiting overpotential is evaluated on the TM-TCNQs as a function of the two variables ΔG(O*-OH*) and ΔG(OH*) and is shown Fig. 3 . Here, ΔG ads(OOH*) is approximated as a function of ΔG ads(OH*) from the scaling relation between OOH* and OH* in Fig. 2. From the volcano plot in Fig. 3, the minimum possible ηlim is found as low as 0.31 V. The best TM-TCNQ for the ORR is found to be Fe-TCNQ with ηlim = 0.33 V. This thermodynamic limiting overpotential is even lower than that on Pt(1 1 1) (ηlim = 0.48 V) calculated with the RPBE functional [20]. Three limiting steps of the ORR on the Fe-TCNQ monolayer with equal differences in free energy change can be found (the first step of reduction O2 to OOH*, the third step of reduction O* to OH* and the fourth step of reduction OH* to H2O). Mn also exhibits very good activity (ηlim = 0.51 V) for ORR with limiting step of OH formation. Ru- and Co-TCNQs have relative higher ηlim (0.61 V, 0.79 V), which are caused by their adsorption of OH* far away from ideal value of 0.9 eV. From the above stability selection, Ru atoms are found easily substituted by protons in aqueous solution. Considering this and the cost of Ru, we will not study Ru-TCNQ monolayer in the following part. Transition metals from Co to Ag provide too weak binding of the intermediates resulting in low activities toward the ORR with the limiting step being O2 reduction to OOH*. Note the Fe-TCNQ monolayer almost reaches the top of the volcano, and weakening the interaction between OH* and the metal in e.g. Mn-TCNQs or Ru-TCNQ will enhance the ORR activity, whereas increasing the interactions between OH* (and OOH*) of Co-TCNQ or Ni-TCNQ are expected to improve activity as well. Here, the two-electron (2e−) reduction of O2 to H2O2 is also taken into account through formation of OOH* (Eq. (21)) followed by (21) OOH* + H+ + e− → * + H2O2 where the unhydrogenated O* atom in OOH* is hydrogenated to form H2O2. Fig. 4 displays the free energy diagram the ORR via the two-electron and four-electron reductions on Fe-TCNQ at different electrode potentials, respectively. At U = 0, all steps are exothermic, so the reaction can spontaneously occur on a Fe-TCNQ monolayer from O2 to H2O. However, the formation of H2O2 via the two-electron pathway is less exergonic than formation of O* in the 4e− reduction, because the released free energy (0.52 eV) by H2O2 is much less than the free energy (2.09 eV) released in the process of converting OOH* to O*. Therefore, 2e− reduction of H2O2 is less efficient than the 4e− pathway. When U = Ulim = 0.90 V, the free energies of O2 to OOH* and O* to H2O become isoenergetic. At the equilibrium potential for the 4e− reduction, the thermodynamic barrier is highest for the limiting step, which is the reduction of O2 to OOH*. The OER is the reverse reaction of the ORR. Thus, the limiting overpotential can be rewritten as the following Eq. (22): (22) η lim = U lim - 1.23 V = max - Δ G 1 , - Δ G 2 , - Δ G 3 , - Δ G 4 / e - 1.23 V Fig. 5 indicates the ideal minimum ηlim is 0.27 V by using the scaling relation between OOH* vs OH* from Fig. 2. The TM-TCNQs are distributed in three different zones corresponding to different limiting steps, and most are quite far from the apex of the activity volcano. The best catalyst for OER among the 12 candidates is identified as Ni-TCNQ whose limiting step is H2O oxidation to OH*. The predicted ηlim is 0.46 V, which is slightly higher than for RuO2 (ηlim = 0.42 eV) [37]. With the same limiting step as the Ni-TCNQ monolayer, Ir and Rh-TCNQs exhibit moderate activity with ηlim of 0.56 and 0.59 V, respectively. According to the above discussion, there is still plenty of room to enhance the catalytic activity such as increasing ΔG(O*) or ΔG(O*-OH*) as none of the TM-TCNQs approaches the optimal η for OER. 3.2 Improving the catalytic performance by coordinating axial ligands Coordinating an axial ligand to the metal centre is expected to be an effective approach [51–53] to improve the ORR and OER performances, which is attributed to changed properties of the metal centres and their interaction with the coordination configuration. For instance, improved ORR activity of FeN4Cx in a phosphoric acid electrolyte, was recently attributed to coordination of phosphate anions to the Fe site [54]. Moreover, ligand-field effects altering the chemical environment of the central TM sites may also lead to modified scaling relations between the reaction intermediates. In experiments, the five and six fold coordination of TM-N4 complexes are common approaches to modify their properties [48]. Therefore, inspired by this technology and a synthesised six fold coordination in Fe-TCNQ materials [26], we study Mn-, Fe-, Co- and Ni-TCNQ sheets near the vertex of the volcano with four different ligands viz. cyano (CN), carbon monoxide (CO), nitrogen oxide (NO), chlorine (Cl). The ligands are initially placed on one side of the monolayer, and the intermediates adsorbed on the other side. The ORR and OER limiting overpotentials of Mn, Fe, Co and Ni-TCNQs with these ligands are shown in Fig. 6 . Among these candidates, Fe-TCNQ-Cl (ηlim = 0.27/0.55 V) and Fe-TCNQ-CN(ηlim = 0.53/0.21 V) exhibit the best catalytic performance for bifunctional ORR/OER activity, followed by Mn-TCNQ-CN (ηlim = 0.37/0.51 V) and Fe-TCNQ-CO (ηlim = 0.67/0.43 V). We notice that after grafting the appropriate ligand (e.g. Cl, CO and CN) onto the metal centre (TM = Mn, Fe, Co), the limiting potential for the OER is significantly decreased. For instance, ηlim for OER on Fe-TCNQ decreases from 0.86 to 0.55 V after Cl coordination primarily because ΔG(O*) increases by 0.24 eV while ΔG(OOH*), and ΔG(OH*) changes less than 0.06 eV. For Mn-TCNQ-CN, ΔG(O*) increases 0.57 eV, while ΔG(OOH*) and ΔG(OH*) increases 0.08 and 0.07 eV, respectively. Consequently, the limiting overpotentials for ORR and OER both decrease. After grafting CN on Fe-TCNQ sheet, ΔG(O*) further increases 0.67 eV leading to a rather low OER limiting over potential of 0.21 V, however, ΔG(OOH*) and ΔG(OH*) increases too much resulting in a higher limiting overpotential of 0.53 V for the ORR. With the CO ligand on Fe-TCNQ, ΔG(OOH*), ΔG(O*), ΔG(OH*) increases by 0.33 eV, 0.72 eV and 0.31 eV. These increases lead to a higher ORR (0.67 V) and lower OER (0.43 V) limiting overpotentials compared to the ligand-free situation. The original scaling relation of ΔG(OH*) and ΔG(O*) is 1.82:1, so enhancement of catalytic performance is attributed to optimized adsorption energies and violating the scaling relations of adsorbates (Fig. S2, Supporting Information). The ORR limiting overpotentials increase in all cases after grafting NO because the binding of all ORR/OER intermediates significantly weakens. To evaluate the bifunctional activity of a catalyst, Schuhmann et al. proposed to use the sum of the ORR and OER overvoltage as a descriptor (here we use ηlim) [55]. MnxOy/NC and CoxOy/NC nanoparticles embedded in a nitrogen doped carbon matrix have been identified as high-performance bifunctional electrocatalysts corresponding to low total ηlim of 0.87 and 0.86 V, respectively. Using the above descriptor, the total limiting overpotentials of the functionalized Fe-TCNQ-Cl/CN/CO and Mn-TCNQ-CN are calculated as 0.82/0.74/1.10 and 0.88 V indicating high catalytic activity of these functionalized metal centers. Taking into account the competition between ligands and intermediates in Fig. S3, we find ligands on one side of the TCNQ monolayer can be formed from exothermic reactions that releases heat in the range from 0.02 to 1.46 eV. The Ni-TCNQ monolayer binds the various ligands the weakest, whereas for the other monolayers there is no longer a correlation between d-band centers and adsorbate binding energy. For instance, binding energies of the first CN unit on Mn- and Fe-TCNQ sheets are −1.19 and −1.43 eV, while for NO unit, binding energies become −1.49 and −1.25 eV, respectively. In general, grafting the second ligand is also an exothermic reaction. The binding strengths of the second CO (−0.54 to 0.02 eV), NO (−0.20 to 0.07 eV) and Cl (−0.74 to −0.4 eV) are moderate. Except for the Ni-TCNQ sheet, the second CN ligand binds on metallic sites strongly, with ligand formation energies in the range from −0.71 to −1.14 eV, as shown in Fig. S3. Therefore, CN will likely block the active metal sites by forming 6-fold coordinated metal sites. In addition, Fig. 6 indicates that NO may reduce ORR catalytic activities by increasing the limiting overpotentials. Cl and CO ligands are therefore more promising ligands than CN and NO to improve activity. Rationalizing the change in intermediate binding energies based on, e.g., Bader charge analysis does not reveal any clear correlation between binding energies and charges of the central metal atoms in the TM-TCNQ monolayers. Central metal atoms carry more positive charge after grating ligands except in the case of Mn-TCNQ-CO, while the E ads values of all the adsorbates decrease consistently. Thus, coordinating various ligands can greatly change the adsorption profiles and violate the original scaling relation providing more space to rational design high active catalysis in Fig. S2. We note that recent experiments also indicate that the Cl anion cannot fully poison iron atoms of FeN4Cx moieties [54], but affects the ORR activity suggesting moderate binding energy of Fe-Cl which is consistent with our DFT calculations. After considering the limiting overpotentials and stabilities of various functionalized TM-TCNQ monolayers, we herein propose Fe-TCNQ-Cl (ηlim = 0.27/0.55 V) and Fe-TCNQ-CO (ηlim = 0.67/0.43 V) as efficient bifunctional catalysts for the ORR/OER. Strain engineering in 2D materials is a feasible technology to achieve tunable electronic properties [56–59]. Previous studies reveal that external strain can change the binding of adsorbates [60], which are able to contribute to the enhancement of catalytic activity [15]. Inspired by this approach, we also perform extensive calculations of TM-TCNQs (TM = Mn, Fe, Co, Ni) to examine effects of strain on the catalytic performance by applying between −3% compressive to 3% tensile strain. The results indicate that ηlim of Mn-TCNQ and Ni-TCNQ for ORR are slightly decreased under 2–3% tensile strain, while ηlim of OER increases a little accordingly. The catalytic performances of other candidates (TM = Fe, Co) for ORR/OER under strain are not improved (see details in Supporting Information). Therefore, applying external strain to improve the ORR/OER activities is less efficient than functionalization on TM-TCNQ monolayers. 4 Conclusion To summarize, we have systematically investigated stabilities and catalytic behaviors of twelve TM-TCNQs toward the ORR and the OER by using density functional theory. Except for Pt-TCNQ, the studied catalysts possess excellent conductivity for fast electron transfer during the catalytic processes. In the absence of grafting ligands, the adsorption strength of reaction intermediates on TM active sites is strongly correlated to the d-band centers. Among the twelve TM-TCNQs, we find Fe-TCNQ to have the lowest limiting overpotential of 0.33 V for the ORR via the four-electron reduction. The limiting overpotential of Ni-TCNQ for the OER is identified as the lowest among 12 candidates. Grafting axial ligands or applying external strain to the TM-TCNQs can further tune the binding energies of reaction intermediates and reduce limiting overpotentials, especially for the OER. Importantly, Fe-TCNQ monolayers with Cl and CO ligands are predicted as efficient bifunctional ORR/OER catalysts. As Fe-TCNQ is already experimentally synthesized, our findings might open novel ways to design durable, non-precious metal, efficient catalysts of ORR/OER in metal-air batteries and fuel cells. coredata.dc:description: The identification of catalytically active and stable bifunctional electrocatalysts for the oxygen reduction and evolution reaction (ORR/OER) would revolutionize rechargeable metal-air batteries and regenerative fuel cell technologies. In this study, we use density functional theory (DFT) calculations to systemically investigate 2D transition metal based tetracyanoquinodimethane (TM–TCNQ, TM = Cr-Cu, Ru-Ag, Pt, Ir) monolayers with single TM atoms catalysts (SACs) distributed periodically with high density. We calculate a lower limiting overpotential of ηlim = 0.33 V for Fe-TCNQ yielding a higher expected activity than that of Pt metal (0.48 V) for the ORR under acidic conditions. The catalytic performance of Fe-TCNQ for OER is, however, surpassed by Ni-TCNQs (ηlim = 0.46 V), which is identified as the highest among the candidates. By applying grafting axial ligands and external strain, the adsorption strength of reaction intermediates on TM reactive sites can be further optimized and enhances the activities of Mn-, Fe- and Ni-TCNQs for the ORR or the OER. Here, Fe-TCNQ-Cl (ηlim = 0.27/0.55 V), followed by Fe-TCNQ-CO (ηlim = 0.67/0.43 V), are predicted as novel, high-performance bifunctional ORR/OER catalysts with comparable limiting overpotentials to those of the best commercially used electrocatalysts, Pt (ORR: ηlim = 0.48 V) and RuO2 (OER: ηlim = 0.42 V). In addition, the recently synthesized Fe-TCNQ possess excellent conductivity with fast electron transfer during the catalytic reactions. These results show 2D TM-TCNQ monolayers are durable, low-cost, and efficient catalysts for the ORR and the OER in metal-air batteries and fuel cells.
coredata.dc:title: 2D transition metal–TCNQ sheets as bifunctional single-atom catalysts for oxygen reduction and evolution reaction (ORR/OER)
